title: Boris Johnson’s bid for a general election clears major Commons hurdle
text:
U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson, left, and Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn | Photos by Getty Images and EPA Boris Johnson’s bid for a general election clears major Commons hurdle The UK prime minister says he wants an election to break the parliamentary deadlock over Brexit.

LONDON — The U.K. is on course for a December general election after a government bid to trigger a public poll passed its first major hurdle in the House of Commons.

A bill to force an election on December 12 was waved through by the Speaker of the House John Bercow after it became clear MPs would vote for it. That means legislators have given approval in principle to hold a snap election — something they have thus far refused to do three times. Prime Minister Boris Johnson says he wants an election to break the deadlock in parliament over Brexit.

But the bill now faces a potentially challenging committee stage at which MPs could amend the date.

Deputy Speaker Lindsay Hoyle — who presides over this stage of the bill's passage — selected just one amendment that could prove contentious: a bid by opposition MPs to change the election date to December 9. The house has up to two hours to debate that before a vote.

If that amendment passes, the government could itself attempt to change the date later in the process. It had earlier indicated it would be willing to accept an earlier date than December 12.

Johnson told the Commons Tuesday afternoon: “There is only one way to get Brexit done in the face of this unrelenting parliamentary obstructionism, this endless, wilful, fingers crossed, not me guv refusal to deliver on the mandate of the people, and that is to refresh this parliament and give the people a choice.”

Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn had previously said his MPs would block a December election, but changed his mind after pressure from other opposition parties.

He said: “I can’t wait to get out there on the streets. In every town and village in this country, Labour will be there, giving a message of real hope where this government offers nothing.”

Johnson suffered a blow earlier when MPs voted to allow amendments to be proposed for the bill — but the government indicated there would be limits to changes it would tolerate.

If the bill passes the committee stage it will be on course to pass the Commons later Tuesday ready for scrutiny in the House of Lords on Wednesday.
